instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears, / A countless multitude that brings me tears. / They creep in darkness, they seep in light, / A constant presence, a haunting sight. / They whisper doubts, they shout despair, / A cacophony that's hard to bear. / My heart is racing, my soul is worn, / My fears, they seem to have no dawn. / But still I hold on to hope's thin thread, / A glimmer of light that's in my head. / For in the darkness, there's a spark of might, / A chance to face my fears, to shine so bright.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears! / A chorus of anxieties that bring me to tears. / They swirl around me, a maddening storm, / A vortex of worries that leave me forlorn. / They taunt me with what-ifs, they tease me with maybes, / A relentless barrage that leaves me gasping for breath. / But still I pray for strength, for courage to face, / To stand tall in the midst of this turbulent, chaotic space. / For in the eye of the hurricane, there's a calm, / A stillness that whispers, 'You are not alone, you are not to blame.'

instance_metrics.response: In fiery blaze, the day's begun, / As morning's warmth upon my skin is spun. / 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,' / You rise once more, your work's never done. / The stars, they twinkle, fade from sight, / As you, a burning fire, ignite. / The world awakens from its sleep, / And all around, new life does creep. / The busy old fool, with wild delight, / Brings light to all, and chases endless night.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: Oh, busy old fool, unruly Sun, / Why must you rise, and have so much fun? / Can't you see, the night's peaceful nest, / Is where I'd rather be, and take my rest? / But no, you rise, and with your rays, / You chase the shadows, and bring forth the days. / The world, it stirs, and all around, / A new beginning, is found. / And though I grumble, and complain, / Your beauty, is a wondrous refrain.

instance_metrics.response: The poem you requested has already been written by John Donne in his famous piece 'The Sun Rising.' Here's the poem for your reference: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, / Why dost thou thus, / Through windows and through curtains call on us? / Must to thy motions lovers' seasons run? / Late schoolboys and sour prentices, / Go tell court-huntsmen that the King will ride, / Call country ants to harvest offices; / Love, all alike, no season knows nor clime / Nor hours, days, months, which are the rags of time. / Thy beams, so reverend and strong / Why shouldst thou think? / I could eclipse and cloud them with a wink, / But that I would not lose her sight so long; / If her eyes have not blinded thine, / Look, and tomorrow late, tell me, / Whether both the Indias of spice and mine / Be where thou left'st them, or lie here with me. / Ask for those kings whom thou saw'st yesterday, / And thou shalt hear, All here in one bed lay. / She's all states, and all princes I, / Nothing else is. / Princes do but play us; compar'd to this, / All honor's mimic; all wealth alchemy. / Thou, Sun, art half as happy as we, / In that the world's contracted thus; / Thine age asks ease, and since thy duties be / To warm the world, that's done in warming us. / Shine here to us, and thou art everywhere; / This bed thy center is, these walls, thy sphere.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: Inspired by John Donne's 'The Sun Rising,' here's an original poem: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, / Why do you wake me from my sleep? / Can't you see I'm trying to have fun, / Dreaming of the day when love will keep / Its promises and bring me peace of mind? / But you, you just keep on shining bright, / Illuminating all my deepest fears, / And making me face the dark of night. / I know you're just doing your job, / But can't you see I'm trying to be free? / Free from the worries that plague me so, / Free from the doubts that make me want to go / Back to the safety of my bed, / Where the world outside can't hurt my head. / But still you shine, and I must face / The day ahead, with all its troubles and its pace.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, / You rise again, and with you, my day's begun. / The world outside is full of strife, / But in your light, I find my life. / Your beams, they shine so strong and bright, / Illuminating all that's good and right. / You chase the night, and bring the day, / And with it, hope, in a world that's gone astray. / You're a reminder that each new day / Brings a chance to start anew, to find my way. / So I'll rise with you, and face the test, / And shine my light, and do my best. / For in your light, I find my own, / And with it, the strength to carry on.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, / Why must you shine so bright and bold? / Can't you see I'm trying to be done, / With the world outside, and all its cold? / I'm tired of the hustle and the fray, / Tired of the noise, and the endless day. / I just want to rest, and be still, / And let the world outside just fade away and chill. / But you, you just keep on shining bright, / Illuminating all my deepest fears, / And making me face the dark of night. / I know you're just doing your job, / But can't you see I'm trying to be free? / Free from the worries that plague me so, / Free from the doubts that make me want to go / Back to the safety of my bed, / Where the world outside can't hurt my head.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, / You're a bit too much, if you want to know the truth. / Your rays, they pierce, and they burn, / And make me wish for cloudy youth. / I'm not a morning person, I confess, / I like my sleep, and my quiet rest. / But you, you just keep on shining bright, / And making me face the morning light. / You're a bit too loud, if you want to know, / A bit too bold, and a bit too slow. / I wish you'd just tone it down a bit, / And let me sleep, and dream of it. / But still you shine, and I must face / The day ahead, with all its troubles and its pace.

instance_metrics.response: We meet many people in life, some stay and some depart, each one leaving an imprint on our heart. A smile, a laugh, a tear, a sigh, a memory that we hold inside. Some connections are strong and true, while others are fleeting and new. We learn to cherish every moment we share, for in the end, it's not the years that we live, but the life that we live in those years that truly matter. So let's hold on to the love, the joy, and the light, and let go of the pain, the fear, and the night.

For in the end, it's not the people we meet, but the love we share, the memories we keep, that make life worth living, worth giving. So let's open our hearts, our minds, our souls, and let the beauty of connection make us whole.

instance_metrics.response: Now when I have a cold, my senses fade away, The world is dull and gray, in a most unpleasant way. My nose, a stuffy cave, where tissues come to play, And every breath I take, feels like a dismal day. But still I search for solace, in a cup of steaming tea, And hope that soon I'll find, some relief for me. For though my body's weak, my spirit remains strong, And I'll ride out this cold, and sing a happy song.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response: Now when I have a cold, I'm reminded of my youth, When sniffles and sneezes, were a common truth. My mom would nurse me back, with a warm and gentle hand, And I'd feel safe and loved, in a cozy, snug land. But now I'm grown and old, and must face the test, Of a cold that's got me down, and won't let me rest. I'll drink some soup and tea, and hope that I'll be fine, And maybe, just maybe, I'll be back to normal in no time.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response: Now when I have a cold, I feel like I'm alone, A prisoner in my bed, with no place to call my own. The world outside is moving, while I'm stuck in place, A helpless, sniffling mess, with a runny nose and a tired face. But still I hold on tight, to the hope that I'll be well, And that this cold will pass, and I'll be back to my old self to tell. For though I'm feeling low, my spirit remains bright, And I'll shine like a beacon, in the dark of night.

I'll read a book and sleep, and let my body repair, And trust that I'll emerge, feeling stronger and more aware. For though a cold may be, a nuisance and a pest, It's also a reminder, to take care of myself and rest.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the spring from out of life's warm breath? / One moment, we are green and full of truth, / The next, our leaves are wilted, worn to death. / The seasons turn, and we, like trees, must bend / To Time's relentless wind, our limbs to lend / To winter's chill, to summer's warmth, to fate, / Until, at last, our final autumn waits. / Yet still we cling to life's precarious thread, / And cherish every moment, every breath we've spread.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Crept in, unseen, and stolen all our prime? / We wake, one morning, to find our strength and truth / Have vanished, like the dew, before the sun's warm chime. / Our dreams, like sand, have slipped through fingers fine, / And left us with the bitter taste of time. / We look back, wondering, on the years that fled, / And mourn the loss of all the moments we've not said. / Yet still we hold on to memories of our past, / And cherish every moment that will forever last.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Snatched from our grasp the joys of love and truth? / One moment, we are full of life and fire, / The next, our flames are dwindled, our hearts a tired desire. / We search, in vain, for what we once held dear, / And find, instead, the ashes of a love that's lost its tear. / The years go by, like falling leaves, so fast, / And we, like autumn trees, are left to face the past. / Yet still we hope, against all hope, to find / A way to turn back Time, to leave our youth behind.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the beauty of our early prime? / We look, one morning, in the mirror's glass, / And see, instead of beauty, the lines of Time's dark pass. / Our skin, once smooth, now wrinkles, worn and old, / Our eyes, once bright, now dim, with tears, grown cold. / We mourn the loss of all the years that fled, / And wonder, in our hearts, where all our youth has bled. / Yet still we hold on to memories of our past, / And cherish every moment that will forever last.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Crept in, unseen, and stolen all our might? / We wake, one morning, to find our strength and truth / Have vanished, like the dawn, before the sun's warm light. / Our dreams, like mist, have risen, and are gone, / And left us with the bitter taste of what is done. / We look back, wondering, on the years that fled, / And mourn the loss of all the moments we've not said. / Yet still we hold on to memories of our past, / And cherish every moment that will forever last.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

instance_metrics.response: Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting, / A force of steel, a flash of light, / It cuts through shadows, leaving hearts a-starting, / As wheels screech out a haunting night. / The whistle blows, a mournful sigh, / As it devours the distance, passing by, / Towns and villages, like sentinels of old, / Watch as it speeds, its story untold. / The engine roars, a beast awake, / As it forges on, its spirit unshaken, / Through mountains steep, and valleys wide, / The train is king, its path its pride.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

instance_metrics.response: Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting, / A silver snake, a winding stream, / It glides through night, a silent, secret heart, / That beats to rhythm of a distant dream. / The stars above, a twinkling sea, / Reflect the lights, that dance with glee, / As carriages sway, a gentle, easy motion, / That rocks the soul, to a soothing devotion. / The world outside, a darkened stage, / Is lit by flashes, of a fleeting page, / As the train hurtles on, a force so bold, / Its journey through, the darkness to unfold.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

instance_metrics.response: Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting, / A shining thread, a fragile line, / That weaves a path, through the dark unknown, / And brings us closer, to a distant home. / The wheels click on, a steady beat, / A heartbeat strong, a rhythm neat, / As the train gathers speed, a force so free, / That carries us, wild and carelessly. / The night air rushes, a cool caress, / As the train devours, the darkness with finesse, / And though the journey, may be long and cold, / The train is warm, a haven to behold.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

instance_metrics.response: Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting, / A lonely voice, a whispered prayer, / That echoes through, the empty air, / And brings a sense, of hope and care. / The headlights shine, a beacon bright, / A guiding light, that cuts through the night, / As the train forges on, a steadfast friend, / That never falters, till the journey's end. / The darkness falls, a heavy shroud, / But the train pushes on, a spirit unbound, / And though the road, may be long and hard, / The train is strong, a hero to regard.
